title: The November has started, so it's time to get together a list of emotions for our #Rothko_Challenge ...

attachments.displayName:
The November has started, so it's time to get together a list of emotions for our #Rothko_Challenge -- results to be posted on the First Friday of December.

If you recall, the idea is to show a colour (or color) representation of an emotion, how it feels to you. Each work (photo of a work) should be abstract enough to give color the leading role. My idea was that you can go anywhere from a new masterpiece (if you feel inspired) to a photo detail of an existing work (as illustrated here with a detail from my own painting), as long as it represents, for you, the color of a particular emotion.

Here is the list I came up with (including your suggestions). My idea was to avoid intense negativity (so as not to unleash negative emotions on unsuspecting G+), but also not to be purely positive...  Also, to have some emotions close enough to allow for subtle distinctions, not just start contrasts. So, here goes:

1. intense desire, passionate need
2. joy, elation
3. jealousy, heartburn
4. content, peacefulness
5. admiration, adoration -- the feeling one gets faced with someone or something genuinely, extraordinarily great
6. deep sadness, mourning
7. frustration

You can create your representations for any or all of them, but it would be nice if each of us did at least three, since colors get most of their meaning(s) in oppositions and relationships.

Any questions?

object.content:
The November has started, so it's time to get together a list of emotions for our #Rothko_Challenge -- results to be posted on the First Friday of December.

If you recall, the idea is to show a colour (or color) representation of an emotion, how it feels to you. Each work (photo of a work) should be abstract enough to give color the leading role. My idea was that you can go anywhere from a new masterpiece (if you feel inspired) to a photo detail of an existing work (as illustrated here with a detail from my own painting), as long as it represents, for you, the color of a particular emotion. 

Here is the list I came up with (including your suggestions). My idea was to avoid intense negativity (so as not to unleash negative emotions on unsuspecting G+), but also not to be purely positive...  Also, to have some emotions close enough to allow for subtle distinctions, not just stark contrasts. So, here goes:

1. intense desire, passionate need
2. joy, elation
3. jealousy, heartburn
4. content, peacefulness
5. admiration, adoration -- the feeling one gets faced with someone or something genuinely, extraordinarily great
6. deep sadness, mourning
7. frustration

You can create your representations for any or all of them, but it would be nice if each of us did at least three, since colors get most of their meaning(s) in oppositions and relationships. 

Any questions?
Are we waiting to post until the first Friday? That was the plan, right?
+Dawn Diamantopoulos -- yes, I thought it would be more interesting, in this case, if we don't directly influence one another in the process.
+Lena Levin, is it OK if we choose our own feeling rather than one from the list?

Of course you can choose your own feelings. I just thought it would be interesting to have a common list, so we could see the variations in our perceptions. So, maybe if you have a feeling (or feelings) in mind, you just tell me, and I add them to the list, so that others could participate (only if you want to, of course).
+Lena Levin, The concept I had in mind was something like "That feeling I get as my daughter's cheek brushes mine when we cuddle".

Wouldn't it be a specific case of joy or peacefulness/contentedness? 

We have briefly discussed the possibility of such situation-related descriptions earlier, and it seemed that they can actually invoke different emotions in different people -- the same situation can be associated with intense joy for one, and with quiet comfort/peacefulness for the other.
Or, in this case, it might be situationally unfamiliar to some participants -- for example, I don't have a daughter, and I am not at all sure that a mother's feelings to her son are identical "in color" to a father's feelings to his daughter; would be even more interesting to see the color, though... :).  

I believe we can reserve such descriptions for presentation of actual works (individual for each of us), and, if possible, "file" them under one of the broader categories...

The bottom line: yes, by all means, your work based on that (or similar) feeling would be most welcome, but if you could loosely associate it with one of our broader categories, it would also participate in this broader comparison of our perceptions.

You're certainly right about people associating situation based descriptions with differing emotions depending on the viewer.

In my case, my experience of the situation I described is only partly represented by joy. There is also adoration, and a good deal of jealousy for her. Another aspect is the sorrow I have for her, knowing what pain and heartache she will face in life that I can never protect her from. And of course there is pride. So much pride in everything she does and for everything she is.

All that to say... Maybe I'll go with adoration. :)
Looks like a good list to work from.  There are a couple on the list that I plan to work on.

title: Google+ List of Comments for an Activity
